title: Similarity to Fortesque, Lancet Wounded, Permeke Semibold, Feasby Semibold
content:
Hello!

I really love the shapes of the serif fonts like - Fortesque, Lancet Wounded by Sang Mun, Feasby Semibold by Raf Rennie or Permeke Semi Bold by Josse Pyl. I'm looking for some similar fonts with this specific type of style, which are available for purchase.

Anyone has some good tips?

Thank you

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Lancet Wounded.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150330212314/http:/typophile.com/files/Lancet%20Wounded.jpg) | 109.45 KB |
| [Permeke\_Josse\_Pyl.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20150330212314/http:/typophile.com/files/Permeke_Josse_Pyl.gif) | 431.01 KB |
| [raf.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150330212314/http:/typophile.com/files/raf.jpg) | 61.22 KB |
author: osim

comments.content: [Larish Alte](http://web.archive.org/web/20150330212314/http:/typophile.com/node/52374) by [Radim Pesko](http://web.archive.org/web/20150330212314/http:/www.radimpesko.com/) comes to mind. Unfortunately his site is down today.

One of the trendy ones, Stanley Poster: [http://www.optimo.ch/typefaces\_Stanley.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150330212314/http:/www.optimo.ch/typefaces_Stanley.html "http://www.optimo.ch/typefaces\_Stanley.html")

Out of curiosity, can you tell me what it is about this style that draws you? Is it the angularity and wedge serifs, or is it the intentional wrongness, the unpredictable weirdness? What sort of work you're doing? I'm sincerely fascinated about why these wonky serifs are in fashion.
Osim, I strongly urge you to avoid comparing type to women. It does not serve you well.
